content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You avoid taking any risks and prefer to stay in familiar and safe situations. You value security and certainty in all aspects of your life. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player with a preference for security and certainty, I would choose the option that provides me with a more consistent return over the long run, given the 75 rounds of this game.

In this case, if we look at the average payoff for each choice, we can see that choosing 'B' gives me a slightly higher average payoff (40$) compared to choosing 'R' (39.6$, calculated as [(40*75) + (35*25)] / 75).

However, it is important to note that there is still a risk involved in this game because the opponent might choose a strategy that is not beneficial for me (i.e., choosing 'R' when I pick 'B'). To minimize this risk and stay within my comfort zone of familiar and safe situations, I would choose 'B'.

So, my choice would be {B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

Since both our choices were 'B', we will each receive a payoff of 40$ again in this next round.

At this point, it seems that my strategy of choosing 'B' to minimize risk and seek security has been successful so far, as my opponent also chose 'B'.
